data.text: Bike Touring Gear Obsession: Don't Buy Expensive Bicycles

Hello everyone , Environment consciousness/fitness has pushed us towards cycling before cycling became fad (15 yrs ago) cost of good cycle was $50 in my country Now co's like trek, giant, specialist , kona etc entered and made cycles cost as much as a 3 year used car The peer pressure is so high in cycling groups to buy only branded cycles, if not you will feel left out Isn't it time customers should decide not to give in to marketing and not buy expensive cycles? This will keep spirit of cycling above everything Cycling shouldn't become a gear obsession hobby ( like photography became due to nikon/canon marketing tactics)
Just as a driver of a Skoda can cover the same ground as a driver of a Rolls Royce, why should a cyclist be dictated to by advertising. Make up your own mind!

data.text: 1. 15 years is more than sufficient for any country to build up cycle by manufacturing infrastructure and brands. 2. Look at prices in of those brands in other countries and convert the prices into your local currency, without including the import duty, if any, to in your country. You are free to complain of the prices between countries are different my than 10 percent. 3. There is cycling beyond cycling groups in anyone country. Look around. Both in your country and outside it. Check if the brands you name are used by commute riders. Finally, this is an issue you can fix by setting up a cycle manufacturing plant yourselves. Do ensure that like Trek and giant, you should make double and triple butted frames with different frame for each model and at least 4 or 5 sizes for each model. Your customers will love a 2 x 9 drivetrain bike weighing below 10 kg. St $ 50. May be, they'll be happy just to get 80 TPI puncture restistant tyres and tubes at $ 50.

I have 3 old 90‚Äôs bikes and I‚Äôm pretty happy with my bikes did Central America and Colombia on an old Japanese Nishiki 1993, but if people wants to buy a Tout Terrain Silkroad or a Koga World Traveler, good for them.

data.text: This is not and should not be an expensive hobby. If somebody wants expensive gear or it helps them get out the door and enjoy it, great!! But you can get just as much enjoyment and fitness on a cheap bike.. Just buck the trend of your snobby cycling circles and ride cheap bikes. I've done that forever, you don't need approval from anybody to enjoy the hobby on your own terms. I'd go a step further and take it as a point of pride that you can do the same thing for less money. Cycling can be notoriously snobby and gear-centric, but you don't have to buy into that culture. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

data.text: I ride a Gunnar. Made in WI. Tools are mostly Park. Arkel panniers out of Canada which is close enough. Front bag by trash messager bags out of MN. Hyperlite bag out of ME. My quilt is made in the states. A good amount of my camping gear is made in America. Not everything but I try to avoid buying stuff from China when possible.

data.text: Just ride the bike you are comfortable riding. I bought a second hand bike last month and now riding it on a 2000 mile camping trip
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: This post is an ideological take on the issue. For me it's an economic one. I can't afford unnecessarily expensive bikes anyway, so I buy cheap used ones, or cheap new ones (and then resell or donate them). So where's the issue? It's ok. Let the "fools" spend their money on expensive stuff. Imagine if through your argument suddenly all cyclists want to switch over to cheap used bikes! That would make them (remember, supply and demand) much more expensive, to the point of making them too inaccessible to people like me. So don't spoil things!
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: I agree but also disagree, so I have to go with the old non-answer ‚Äúwell it depends‚Äù. It depends what kind of riding you do and it depends on what level your riding is at
data.author: Andrew Andrew Andrew

data.text: I worked in bike shops for years and there are two best deals in any bicycle brand. One is the bike one step above the cheapest bike from a major brand. You will get a decent bike without spending too much. The other is the bike one step below the most expensive bike in their line-up. You will get a top notch machine, just not the most expensive.
data.author: Curtis Evans

data.text: and buy good tires would be a decent advise.

data.author: Petar Belobrajdic

data.text: I love the one step up from the bottom of the major makers comment. I have lived it for years. I own a bicycle tour company and currently about 35 old Cannondale frames. I have rebuilt them all many times over using one step from the bottom components. It's a great working philosophy.
data.author: Walt Rowland

data.text: An interesting observation I've noticed while touring for the last 5 years, is people on serious long tours, from 6 month to a few years, ride cheap bike. Just a few hours ago I meet a German guy who's riding on a bike he bought for ‚Ç¨50 and has been on the road since March with no end date. A few weeks ago I met a 21yo kid from England. In Austria, while hitchhiking around the world, he was informed about retiring his thumb for a bike. He bought a bike for ‚Ç¨100. A family I rode with for a few weeks all have used bikes (parents and a 9 and 11yo girls). A Spanish YouTube couple also are on bikes they got for less than $200. My bike was on he expensive side worth $1800 but the company have me an $800 discount.. True tourers don't give a $#^@ about the tech as much. It's about the journey. Same about what we carry. I'm with a 55kg loaded bike. In the last 2.5 months, I put 3500km through the Balkan mountain Romania, and Turkey with +34,000 in elevation and did 2 days, each with over 200km. Those that buy the expensive bikes and UL gear are doing it because they can or because they believe the marketing. They usually do short bike packing trips or a once in a life time tour for a few months or 1 long trip per year based on the days they can get off work. They have the means. So what. It makes them feel good, or happy, or whatever the internal reason, it's theirs alone. Nothing wrong with it. That said, technology is expensive to progress. R&D isn't cheap. Prices go up because the market asks for it. That doesn't mean there aren't economical bikes out there. Som people ride old bikes their parents had or whatever sentimental reason. Again their bike, their choice. When I zoom by a roadie on the flats or pass bikepackers with less then half the weight I carry, or other tourers I ride with for a day or a few weeks, assume I'm a "beast". I'm not. Im just 170cm short and weight 68kg. Still have a beer belly. I just have a good drivetrain to help me climb up to 25% inclines and have been accustomed to it doing it daily with rarely any rest days. It's 20% bike, 80% mental. I can go and go until someone needs to stop. Expensive gear does the trick at the professional level. For the rest of us, those $400 clipless shoes don't make a difference. I ride with regular sandals and sometimes barefoot when I'm dripping wet. Those with all the expensive gear are divided into 2 camps: easy going humble people or asshats who think they are gods gift because they have the "better" gear. The later is a much smaller group and are usually roadies who don't tour, or some diehard bikepackers who try to reach the destination as fast as possible.. luckily, they are less common IMO
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: I've only purchased one new bike in my life, now a 77 year old. I pretty much ride daily, weather permitting. I've done six double century rides, all on used bikes. I couldn't care less about disc brakes, the latest popular add-on. Yes, they're better in adverse weather, but these days I'm a pretty cautious rider. So what is the need for me? I have four bikes, all used and all highly appreciated for their specific purposes and uses.

data.text: its choice really for me i know my new gear will last me for years to come ill weather it in and was happy to spend $$$ over 2 years for it always looked for bargains new though.. had bumped into few bike tourist on road who only spent few hundreds instead of thousands for the gear and bike. one even paid $80 for surley LH. just a choice really.
data.author: Petar Belobrajdic

data.text: well. it depends on the type of cyclist you are. I once had a conversation with a friend who is a bike fiend..(in a good natured way) and he loves biking as much as eating. He once bought a very cheap bike from Wal mart. That bike only lasted all of 1 year before falling apart. After that, he decided to prefer a higher quality built bike by Specialized or such like. So if you are a newbie, just learning to ride the bike, then yes, go for a cheap bike from Target or Walmart. but if you are a very strong and competitive cyclist, then I would think its better to buy a bike designed and built by a higher quality company. (I don't mean to push name brand, or push for buying expensive bike) Higher quality bike tend to have bike components that last longer and is able to handle the strength of the cyclist, and the speed that the cyclist can ride at. Just my thoughts. (The highest speed I ride at on my trusty Canadian made expensive and heavy steel Mountain bike is at 35 miles per hour. Sorry for bragging)
data.author: Paul Kvarnberg

data.text: sigh. how about you do you boo and let everyone else enjoy what they like doing. sounds like you need to develop belief in yourself rather than diss others to make yourself feel better. frankly, it is horses for courses. a $50 walmart bike will not do what a several thousand dollar road bike can, which cant do what a well packed touring bike can do, and an mtb is great for those difficult terrain mountain single tracks, etc, etc.
data.author: Jennifer Hocking

data.text: there is no need for that attitude. The point is that, yes, a cheap bike will generally not make the grade as a reliable tourer but it is also perfectly justifiable to point out the marketing aspects of bike touring and the gear involved. Touring should be available to everybody and if that means touring on a cheap bike (which I have done perfectly enjoyably) then understand the limitations and go for it. There are always fashionistas in every sport and pastime that want to keep it exclusive and there will always be people pointing this out. Please don't disparage people for doing so.

data.text: Simply ignore everything but engineering, ergonomics and budget. Get what works. Frames matter little namewise. Think material and the maker‚Äôs rep. Components are important and are best from large factories. After several decades on xt, Im moving onto internal. 6 speeds was fine. Thinner chains every year only brought harder tuning and quicker wear. And dont forget the saddle. Tubular cromo or ti rails allow the frame to flex requiring minimal pads which rub. Screw culture. Get cancelled to be free. Cancelled and riding since the 80s. Its good to be free

data.text: I bought a $500 guitar many years ago because I really couldn't hear the difference between the $500 guitar and the $2500 guitars... but after playing for many years, my ear developed to the point where it was a night and day difference. So it is with bicycles. Years of riding will develop your ability to feel the difference. As a rule, more expensive bike are superior... But if you never refine your tastes, more expensive will only seem like a waste. But moving down in quality from whatever you are used to will almost immediatly seem unacceptable.

data.author: Victoria Eckenroth

data.text: In 2007 I started planning a custom build, I chose a Rohloff hub. At the time with minimal choice on Rohloff-specific frames I opted for a custom frame then built the bike up myself, each & every component I chose was the highest standard, so needless to say it was expensive, but, having never owned a brand new, or expensive car, it's price was no issue. Now, it's completed three world tours, with 96,000km on it, albeit for a few [expected] wheel issues I've never had a problem whatsoever with it. Money indeed well invested. Also now, since my first big tour, have been car-free for 12 years.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: "Rohloff-specific frames"?
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Yes, the left-hand drop out need to be longer for the internal torque-arm to push against (see pic. . . . or the other [ugly] option is use one of their adaptors but then it makes the hub look like an add-on/derailier upgrade, as opposed to a specific fit. The frame Maker (Bristol's Argos Cycles) had not used them before so I bought a dxf-file drawing for a pair from an Australian frame-maker (Green Speed Cycles), & modified it with my initials, then had them laser cut from a Birmingham fabriactor in stainless steel, then sent them to Argos Cycles to fit..& polish up. (as requested I also had 2 pairs made with an 'A', for Argos Cycles stock).
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: The derailleur hanger is for mounting the chain tensioner.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: Stop wanking on brands!! 40 years ago, some people rode around the world without branded bike, and nowadays hundred on people still do the same! No need an expensive bike to have fun and adventure! I still ride my Breezer mtb, bought in 1995, it is still my faithfull steed ! Fuck the fashion of expensives bikes! Just ride!
data.author: Fend La Buche

data.text: not all the people are obsessed with/can afford branded latest model expensive bikes. For instance, most of my bikes are branded (becoz of high quality) but used & older models so they are much cheaper. I also still have a 15 yr old bike that I have many good memories & still ride sometimes. Bikes are good investments!! In my view, so much better than jewelry or other ‚Äúuseless‚Äù things which are just for the look!!
data.author: Astra Ng

data.text: It's a difficult one and I wouldn't knock anyone for their bike or what they pay for it. I am 55 and have been able to build a touring bike with decent equipment. However a cheap setup may work and good luck to those on a budget üëç
data.author: Stephen Shields

data.text: Doubt you got a $50 bike, even back then that was serviceable?
data.author: Alan Ferrier

data.text: I bought an older Litespeed titanium for $600 (road bike)‚Ä¶ switched out better componentry and it rides ever bit and fast as my full carbon bike
data.author: John Mills

data.text: Buy what you can afford then build the machine of your body.. Then if you want a bike with better components, save for that. I road an old Mongoose and thought it was a ton better than my Walmart piece of junk. Then I rode a Liv and realized what I was missing, so I saved for that. You are only competing with yourself and if you're happy and getting out there on what you have then enjoy yourself! I did a half century ride with a friend recently and I was the only one in regular clothes and shoes (no jersey or clips) with my lunch bungee corded to my rack... On a 20 year old road bike I found on Facebook marketplace. Who the heck cares? I still crossed the finish line and had fun doing it. I don't really mind looking like a pauper--it's good for building confidence in myself apart from what others think... Ride on! üö≤
data.author: Sue Marotto Nardino

data.text: I cycle older bikes and am not a member of a club. On the one hand, I think that spending on very expensive components with negligible return can be a bit silly. There are professionals, and they want the very best equipment. Other cyclists are going to want the same equipment as the professional cyclists, even if they don't really need it. Similarly, people buy performance cars that they can never fully utilise on a public road - because it's the fastest, or the most expensive. It's status oriented. They've spent a lot of money on their equipment,so maybe they need to show off to others that they have the best gear. I don't see why that has to be a problem. People have a lot of disposable income and this is one of the ways they use it. I enjoy rebuilding bikes as a hobby, and most of mine are salvage or second hand. I get alot of enjoyment and satisfaction from rebuilding old bikes, so if people are enjoying themselves spending thousands on bikes and equipment, why not let them enjoy themselves that way?! Be assertive about what you like, and allow others to enjoy themselves in their own way too. If someone is being rude about the cost and quality of their expensive carbon fibre bike, you can always just say that you think you see a scratch on the frame - and then cycle away! üòÜ
data.author: Bran Nno

data.text: Don't know what to tell you. Here in Austria, 50‚Ç¨ will not even buy you a second hand bike. And expensive bikes are often far nicer to ride. This said, people are indeed crazy when it comes to buying popular brands. I understand it to a certain level, but quite often one can get something in similar quality for far less money if it isn't from a special brand. Don't get me started with cars or smartphones... FYI, I've been driving a 2-nd hand bike that I bought more than decade ago all over the place for years. Brand is "ghost", which sounds nice to me but otherwise has no real impact. Frankly, I couldn't care less if someone found it nice or ugly or "not the right brand" - what I care about is that it drives well.
data.author: Denis Havlik

data.text: Some poeple use cheap shoes, doesnt mean they are better for walking... I can use a 50 dollar bike if necessary but if Im making a 6000 km journey I have a much better chance of getting there with a bike costing a bit more.
data.author: Tommy B√§ck

data.text: Who cares what they think? If your wallet can't afford it, accept it. Just buy something what you could afford and enjoy the ride. I ride a cheap bike in comparison to those brand you named and it still brings me to those places those expensive bike could reach. so really, no issue. it's all in the head.
data.author: Jason Lian

data.text: Secondhand bikes rule!
data.author: Hugh Wilson

data.text: A lot of people mentioned "consumerism" here in comments. I think the real consumerism (and waste of material) is that cheap junk bikes are being sold at all (and people buying them). I've seen so many people having their cheap Chinese e-bikes one after another. Or noname mountain bikes. I mean, crap bikes just don't serve too long. And because they are cheap no one bothers to fix them as soon as something serious happens, people just buy the next one üòñ And at the same time I see people who use their old reliable mountain bike for 10+ years because it's a good quality and because it makes more sense to fix it and ride some more years than buy a new one. And I see people who have done pretty solid mileage on their e-bikes with Bosch (and other big brands') motors. And it's still possible to get spare parts, unlike with some noname products.
data.author: Alex Rybakoff

data.text: Bhai, you are coming under peer pressure and looking into too much social media. If you love to ride, just buy what suits your budget. If you look into the car and motorbike industry, it‚Äôs the same. Be it the market, the social media or YouTube. All just wants of talk about the latest and best. But, do everyone ride the latest and the best. Just like imported cars/motorbike is more expensive. So is the case with bikes. Did high end cars and bikes ever was or is cheap. Then finally, comes our desi mentality, ‚ÄúImported hai toh accha hoga.‚Äù Firefox did bring in a few models of road bike, but the market was like, ‚Äúyeh toh Chini maal hai‚Äù. Bhai, just ride what you can afford. Don‚Äôt come into peer pressure. People are doing Kanyakumari to Kashmir on normal Hero cycles. If show off is more important to you, then no comments.
data.author: Junaid Parvez
